modelInfo.description:
Claude Sonnet 4 significantly enhances the capabilities of its predecessor, Sonnet 3.7, excelling in both coding and reasoning tasks with improved precision and controllability. Achieving state-of-the-art performance on SWE-bench (72.7%), Sonnet 4 balances capability and computational efficiency, making it suitable for a broad range of applications from routine coding tasks to complex software development projects. Key enhancements include improved autonomous codebase navigation, reduced error rates in agent-driven workflows, and increased reliability in following intricate instructions. Sonnet 4 is optimized for practical everyday use, providing advanced reasoning capabilities while maintaining efficiency and responsiveness in diverse internal and external scenarios.

Read more at the [blog post here](https://www.anthropic.com/news/claude-4)

msg-1758700701-j9WboRIoSAbn79YrOSCi.content:
Here is an overview of NoSketch Engine and Sketch Engine for digital humanities researchers and developers.

### Sketch Engine

Sketch Engine is a commercial, web-based corpus analysis tool. It provides access to massive text corpora and powerful analytical functions through a graphical user interface.

#### Primary Uses

*   Analyzing word behavior in very large, pre-existing text corpora.
*   Generating "word sketches," which are one-page summaries of a word's collocations and grammatical patterns.
*   Finding concordance lines (Key Word in Context) for specific search queries.
*   Extracting multi-word expressions, terminology, and keywords.
*   Comparing word usage across different corpora or sub-corpora.
*   Creating a personal corpus by uploading text or using the integrated web crawler.

#### Limitations

*   It is a subscription-based service, which can be a cost barrier.
*   As a cloud-based platform, it may not be suitable for working with highly sensitive or private data.
*   Users have limited control over the back-end processing and server environment.
*   The web interface, while powerful, can have a steep learning curve for new users.

### NoSketch Engine

NoSketch Engine is the open-source, local version of the software that powers Sketch Engine. It allows researchers to build a corpus query engine on their own server or computer.

#### Primary Uses

*   Building and querying custom corpora on a local machine or private server.
*   Analyzing sensitive or proprietary text data in a secure environment.
*   Integrating a powerful corpus engine into custom digital humanities tools and applications via its API.
*   Learning the fundamentals of corpus engine architecture without subscription costs.
*   Gaining complete control over corpus compilation, annotation, and indexing.

#### Limitations

*   It requires significant technical expertise to install, configure, and maintain.
*   Users must supply, compile, and manage all of their own corpus data.
*   It does not come with pre-built corpora.
*   Getting advanced features like word sketches to work requires deep linguistic and technical knowledge to write "sketch grammars."
*   The standard web interface (`Bonito`) is more basic than the commercial version.

msg-1758700701-q5g5zMLHllTg3OhLWfz1.content:
# NoSketch Engine and Sketch Engine

## What They Are

- **Sketch Engine**: Commercial web-based corpus analysis tool
- **NoSketch Engine**: Open-source version of Sketch Engine
- Both designed for corpus linguistics and text analysis research

## Primary Uses

### Corpus Analysis
- Create and analyze large text corpora
- Search for words, phrases, and grammatical patterns
- Generate concordances and keyword-in-context displays
- Compare language usage across different texts or time periods

### Linguistic Research
- Study word collocations and associations
- Analyze grammatical structures and syntax
- Track language change over time
- Investigate register and genre variations

### Digital Humanities Applications
- Historical text analysis
- Literary corpus studies
- Sociolinguistic research
- Cross-linguistic comparisons

## Key Features

### Text Processing
- Automatic text preprocessing and tokenization
- Part-of-speech tagging and lemmatization
- Support for multiple languages
- Custom corpus compilation tools

### Analysis Tools
- Word sketches showing grammatical relations
- Frequency analysis and statistics
- N-gram extraction
- Parallel corpus alignment

## Limitations

### NoSketch Engine
- Requires technical expertise for installation and configuration
- Limited documentation compared to commercial version
- Fewer pre-built corpora available
- More complex setup process

### Sketch Engine
- Subscription-based pricing model
- Limited customization options
- Dependency on internet connection
- Storage limitations for large corpora

### General Limitations
- Steep learning curve for new users
- Limited support for non-European languages
- Requires substantial computational resources for large corpora
- Complex licensing issues for some text sources

## Best Use Cases

### Choose NoSketch Engine For
- Budget-constrained projects
- Need for extensive customization
- Local data processing requirements
- Long-term archival projects

### Choose Sketch Engine For
- Quick project startup
- Access to pre-built corpora
- Regular technical support needs
- Collaborative research projects

msg-1758700701-tmfq3CFFcFJ4Q9NjOdju.content:
### Sketch Engine
#### Overview
- Sketch Engine is a web-based corpus linguistics tool developed by Lexical Computing.
- It supports analysis of large text corpora in over 90 languages.

#### Primary Uses
- Generating word sketches to show collocations and grammatical patterns.
- Creating concordances for keyword-in-context searches.
- Building thesauri and identifying synonyms or related terms.
- Analyzing parallel corpora for translation studies.
- Supporting lexicography, language teaching, and digital humanities research.

#### Limitations
- Requires a paid subscription for full access.
- Web-based interface limits offline use and customization.
- Data upload and processing can be slow for very large corpora.
- Potential privacy concerns with cloud-stored user data.
- Advanced features may require technical expertise.

### NoSketch Engine
#### Overview
- NoSketch Engine is an open-source corpus query system based on the Manatee engine.
- It serves as a free alternative to Sketch Engine, focusing on core querying without advanced sketching.

#### Primary Uses
- Indexing and querying large text corpora efficiently.
- Performing concordance searches and frequency analyses.
- Supporting custom corpus building for research in linguistics and digital humanities.
- Integrating with tools like Bonito for web interfaces.
- Enabling local installations for data-sensitive projects.

#### Limitations
- Lacks word sketch functionality available in Sketch Engine.
- Requires technical setup, including compilation and server configuration.
- No built-in support for parallel corpora or thesaurus generation.
- Limited to command-line or basic web interfaces without extensions.
- Performance may vary based on hardware for very large datasets.

msg-1758700701-1tJPgvrZgKlFH9mrFGfU.reasoning:
**Clarifying NoSketch Engine features**

In NoSketch Engine, the "word sketches" feature is accessible via Bonito if you have the appropriate Sketch Grammar file (.skg) for your language. I'm a bit unclear about whether the algorithms are proprietary or if the original "word sketches" algorithm is open-source. I believe NoSketch Engine focuses on concordancing, frequency lists, collocations, and more, but it lacks some features that Sketch Engine offers, like large corpora and automatic processes. It’s self-hosted and requires specific setups.**Comparing Sketch Engine and NoSketch Engine**

Sketch Engine is a commercial service, either SaaS or on-premises, with extensive corpora for many languages and a user-friendly interface. It offers tools for building corpora, tagging, lemmatization, and tokenization through a comprehensive toolchain. WebBootCaT helps build web corpora, while TenTen provides huge crawled corpora and GDEX offers useful dictionary examples. For research in digital humanities, it’s used in areas like corpus linguistics and discourse analysis. However, NoSketch has challenges, such as a steep learning curve and limited documentation.**Reviewing Performance and Features**

The performance of a C++ engine is promising, with potential for scaling to large corpora, though memory and configuration might be challenging. Multi-user management is somewhat limited, along with security and backup features. For Sketch Engine, costs include subscription fees and data privacy concerns for sensitive corpora, and there are restrictions on customization and sharing. Input formats include vertical lists and CQL. NoSketch Engine, on the other hand, lacks built-in cloud corpora, automatic crawling, and tagging, which results in a smaller ecosystem and uncertain maintenance status.**Explaining Word Sketch Features**

The Word Sketch feature has limited support, depending on the availability of sketch grammars, and its coverage is not as extensive as in Sketch Engine. It's important to note that NoSketch is GPL licensed. The Manatee-open and Bonito are also GPL-compatible. Sketch Engine, on the other hand, is commercial but offers academic discounts.

I should include a section on when to choose each engine, data pipeline tips, and mention their primary uses and limitations for digital humanities researchers. Integration with digital humanities workflows, reproducibility, scripting, and APIs are essential points too. Lastly, NoSketch is maintained by Lexical Computing and is older than Sketch Engine.**Structuring the Comparison Document**

I want to ensure we address installation complexity for NoSketch. I think a structured approach would help make everything clear.

I can divide the document into sections:
- **Overview:** I'll include both NoSketch Engine and Sketch Engine.
- **Primary uses:** Separate bullet points for each engine's uses.
- **Key features:** This could be optional.
- **Limitations:** Discuss limitations for both NoSketch and Sketch Engine.
- **Data, deployment, and licensing.**
- **When to choose which.**
- **Interoperability and APIs.**
- **Caveats for reproducible digital humanities research.**

I'll keep bullets short, limit heavy formatting, and be cautious about claims regarding features like "GDEX" and "Thesaurus."
msg-1758700701-1tJPgvrZgKlFH9mrFGfU.content:
Overview
- NoSketch Engine: Open-source corpus query platform.
- Sketch Engine: Commercial corpus query and building platform (SaaS and on-prem).

Primary uses (both)
- Concordancing with CQL queries.
- Frequency lists and collocations.
- POS/lemma-aware searches (if tagged).
- Diachronic and genre analysis.
- Terminology and keyword extraction (stronger in Sketch Engine).
- Pedagogical and lexicographic workflows.

NoSketch Engine — primary uses
- Self-host corpora for bespoke projects.
- Reproduceable pipelines under full control.
- Teaching environments without per-seat costs.
- Method development and customization.

Sketch Engine — primary uses
- Instant access to large, ready-made corpora (many languages).
- Rapid corpus building from web and uploads.
- Word Sketches, Sketch Diff, and thesaurus for lexicography.
- Turnkey term extraction and keywording.
- Collaboration via web UI and API.

Key features
- Shared: CQL, concordance, frequency, collocation, KWIC export.
- NoSketch: `manatee-open` indexer; `bonito` web UI; custom attributes.
- Sketch Engine: Word Sketches, GDEX, distributional thesaurus, WebBootCaT, parallel corpora tools, dashboards, API.

Limitations — NoSketch Engine
- No bundled large corpora.
- No built-in web crawling or auto-tagging pipeline.
- Setup is complex (verticalization, tagging, indexing).
- UI is basic; fewer visualization and reporting tools.
- Word Sketches depend on available sketch grammars; coverage is uneven.
- Documentation and community support are limited.
- User management and access control are minimal.
- Maintenance burden and server ops fall on you.

Limitations — Sketch Engine
- Subscription cost and quotas (storage, API limits).
- Some algorithms and resources are proprietary.
- Reproducibility can be affected by platform updates.
- Limited low-level customization compared to self-hosting.
- Data privacy concerns for sensitive corpora on SaaS (on‑prem mitigates).
- Export limits may constrain large-scale downstream processing.

Data and formats
- Both prefer verticalized text (one token per line) with positional attributes.
- Both support structural attributes (documents, paragraphs, metadata).
- Best results with lemmatized and POS-tagged input.

APIs and integration
- NoSketch: Command-line and config-driven; indirect scripting around `manatee-open`. Community Python bindings exist but are sparse.
- Sketch Engine: REST API for queries, word sketches, term extraction, and corpus management. SDK examples and client libraries exist.

Performance and scale
- NoSketch: Efficient C++ index; scales well if tuned; you manage hardware.
- Sketch Engine: Scales transparently to very large corpora; provider manages performance.

Licensing
- NoSketch Engine: GPL (open source).
- Sketch Engine: Commercial; academic plans available.

When to choose NoSketch Engine
- You need full control, offline use, or strict reproducibility.
- You have custom annotations or experimental schemas.
- You can invest in deployment and maintenance.

When to choose Sketch Engine
- You need immediate results and rich lexicographic features.
- You rely on large, multilingual corpora and ready-made grammars.
- You want a maintained platform with support and APIs.

Common pitfalls
- Mismatched tagsets reduce feature quality (both platforms).
- Poor tokenization/lemmatization degrades collocations and sketches.
- Inadequate metadata hinders subcorpus design and diachronic analysis.

Reproducibility tips
- Pin taggers, tokenizers, and sketch grammars to versions.
- Archive verticalized input and index configs.
- Log CQL queries and parameters; export results with metadata.

msg-1758701027-a1y67StGfgrWZ1gfcR7x.content:
Of course. Here is a comparison of major alternatives to Sketch Engine and NoSketch Engine for corpus analysis, with a preference for open-source, self-hostable options, projected as of September 2025.

The landscape for corpus tools generally divides into two categories: integrated, user-friendly platforms (often commercial) and flexible, powerful open-source toolkits that require more technical configuration. The following table compares established products and ecosystems that are highly likely to remain prominent.

### Comparison of Corpus Analysis Tools (September 2025)

| Product / Ecosystem | License | Price | Hosting Options | Concordancing (KWIC) | Collocation Analysis | Keyword & Term Extraction | Word Sketches / Grammatical Patterns¹ | Web GUI | API / Programmatic Access |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Sketch Engine** | Commercial | Subscription | Cloud (SaaS) | Yes | Yes | Yes | Yes (Core Feature) | Yes (Advanced) | Yes (REST API) |
| **NoSketch Engine** | GPL-2.0 | Free | Self-hosted (Server) | Yes | Yes | Yes | Yes (Requires custom grammar) | Yes (Basic) | Yes (REST API) |
| **CQPweb** | GPL-3.0 | Free | Self-hosted (Server) | Yes | Yes | Yes | No | Yes (Advanced) | No (Uses CQP query language) |
| **spaCy** | MIT | Free | Self-hosted, Local | Via custom code | Via custom code | Via custom code | Via custom code | No (Library only) | Yes (Core Feature) |
| **AntConc** | Freeware | Free | Local (Desktop App) | Yes | Yes | Yes | No | N/A (Desktop GUI) | No |
| **Python Ecosystem** (NLTK, Gensim, pandas) | Open Source (Various) | Free | Self-hosted, Local | Via custom code | Via custom code | Yes | Via custom code | Via custom code² | Yes (Core Feature) |
| **WMatrix** | Commercial | Subscription | Cloud (SaaS) | Yes | Yes | Yes | No (Focus is on semantic tagging) | Yes (Advanced) | Limited / None |

---

**Notes on Table Entries:**

1.  **Word Sketches / Grammatical Patterns:** This is the signature feature of Sketch Engine, providing a one-page summary of a word's collocational behavior parsed by grammatical relations (e.g., subject-of, object-of). While `NoSketch Engine` can produce them, it requires advanced user skill to write the necessary "sketch grammars" for a given language. Other tools require you to program this functionality from scratch.
2.  **Web GUI (Python Ecosystem):** With Python, you can build a custom web front-end using frameworks like `Flask` or `Django`, but it is not an out-of-the-box feature.

msg-1758701027-5ColNgVqumwrv7Zq6jFW.content:
# Corpus Analysis Platform Alternatives

**Note**: My knowledge extends to April 2024, so I cannot provide information about developments specifically as of September 2025. The following represents major alternatives available up to my knowledge cutoff.

| Platform | License | Price | Hosting Options | Major Corpus Analysis Features |
|----------|---------|-------|-----------------|-------------------------------|
| **NoSketch Engine** | GPL v2 | Free | Self-hosted Linux/Unix | Word sketches, concordances, collocations, frequency analysis, custom corpora |
| **Sketch Engine** | Commercial | Subscription (~€50-500+/month) | Cloud-hosted, on-premise available | Advanced word sketches, parallel corpora, 600+ pre-built corpora, trend analysis |
| **CQPweb** | GPL v2 | Free | Self-hosted Linux/Apache | CQP query language, statistical analysis, user management, corpus comparison |
| **ANNIS** | Apache 2.0 | Free | Self-hosted Linux/Java | Multi-layer annotation search, syntactic trees, complex linguistic queries |
| **BlackLab** | Apache 2.0 | Free | Self-hosted Linux/Java | Fast full-text search, complex pattern matching, REST API, web interface |
| **TXM** | GPL v2/CeCILL | Free | Self-hosted Linux/Windows | Textometry, statistical analysis, R integration, XML/TEI support |
| **Voyant Tools** | GPL v3 | Free | Self-hosted or web | Text visualization, topic modeling, word clouds, trend analysis |
| **IMS Open Corpus Workbench** | GPL | Free | Self-hosted Linux/Unix | CQP query processor, large corpus handling, linguistic annotation support |
| **#LancsBox** | Free (academic) | Free for research | Desktop + web components | Collocation analysis, keyness, GraphColl visualization, KWIC |
| **CorporaCoCo** | Apache 2.0 | Free | Self-hosted web | Corpus comparison, keyword analysis, collocation networks |

## Key Considerations

### Top Open Source Recommendations
- **CQPweb**: Most feature-complete alternative to Sketch Engine
- **BlackLab**: Best performance for large corpora
- **TXM**: Strongest statistical analysis capabilities
- **ANNIS**: Best for syntactically annotated corpora

### Installation Complexity
- **Easiest**: Voyant Tools, #LancsBox
- **Moderate**: BlackLab, TXM
- **Complex**: CQPweb, ANNIS, NoSketch Engine

### Scalability
- **Large corpora**: BlackLab, IMS CWB, CQPweb
- **Medium corpora**: TXM, NoSketch Engine
- **Small-medium corpora**: Voyant Tools, #LancsBox

**Recommendation**: For most digital humanities projects requiring local hosting, **CQPweb** offers the best balance of features, community support, and Sketch Engine-like functionality.

msg-1758701027-TnQBA8nc0cR1SXm8ZJMb.content:
| Tool | License | Price | Hosting Options | Concordance Search | Collocations/Word Sketches | Frequency Analysis | Custom Corpus Building | Multi-Language Support | Other Notable Features |
|------|---------|-------|-----------------|---------------------|----------------------------|---------------------|--------------------------|-------------------------|-------------------------|
| NoSketch Engine | Open-source (GPL) | Free | Local (Linux servers), self-hosted web interface via Bonito | Yes | No (lacks word sketches) | Yes | Yes | Yes (over 50 languages) | Efficient querying for large corpora; command-line tools |
| Sketch Engine | Proprietary | Subscription (from €5/month for individuals; enterprise pricing varies) | Primarily cloud-based; on-premise for enterprise | Yes | Yes (advanced word sketches) | Yes | Yes | Yes (over 90 languages) | Thesaurus generation; parallel corpora support |
| Corpus Workbench (CWB) | Open-source (GPL) | Free | Local (Linux servers), command-line or with web interfaces like CQPweb | Yes | Basic (via queries) | Yes | Yes | Yes (multiple languages with encoding support) | Positional and structural queries; highly efficient for large datasets |
| AntConc | Open-source (custom free license) | Free | Local (desktop app; can run on Linux servers via Wine or similar) | Yes | Yes (collocate tool) | Yes | Limited (via file import) | Yes (basic Unicode support) | N-gram analysis; keyword extraction; portable and user-friendly |
| BlackLab | Open-source (Apache 2.0) | Free | Local (Linux servers), integrates with Apache Lucene for web/search apps | Yes | Yes (via metadata and patterns) | Yes | Yes | Yes (extensible for languages) | High-performance search; supports annotations and metadata; API integration |
| TXM (Textometrie) | Open-source (GPL) | Free | Local (Linux servers), desktop or server modes | Yes | Yes (co-occurrences) | Yes | Yes | Yes (multiple languages) | Statistical text analysis; visualization tools; TEI-compatible |
| KorAP | Open-source (BSD) | Free | Local (Linux servers), web-based backend | Yes | Yes (complex patterns) | Yes | Yes | Yes (focus on German, but extensible) | Virtual corpora; annotation layers; federated search |
| LancsBox | Open-source (CC BY-NC 4.0 for academic use) | Free for non-commercial | Local (desktop; Linux compatible) | Yes | Yes (GraphColl for collocations) | Yes | Yes | Yes (multiple languages) | Network graphs; time-series analysis; easy GUI |
| Wordsmith Tools | Proprietary | Paid (one-time license ~£50-100) | Local (Windows; Linux via emulation) | Yes | Yes | Yes | Limited | Yes | Concordance plotting; mutual information scores |

| Product | License | Price | Hosting options | Concordance/CQL | POS/Lemma aware | Collocations | Keywords/Term extraction | Word sketches/thesaurus | Trends/diachronic | Parallel corpora | Web corpus build | API |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| NoSketch Engine | GPL v2+ | Free | Self-host Linux; Docker (community) | Yes (CQL) | Yes (if annotated) | Yes | Keywords only | Yes (with sketch grammars) | Partial | Yes (alignment) | No | Limited (CLI/scripts) |
| Sketch Engine | Commercial | Subscription; on‑prem by quote | SaaS; On‑prem Linux | Yes (CQL) | Yes | Yes | Yes | Yes | Yes | Yes | Yes (WebBootCaT) | Yes (REST) |
| CWB + CQPweb | GPL (CWB v2, CQPweb v3) | Free | Self-host Linux | Yes (CQL) | Yes | Yes | Keywords; no terms | No | Partial | Yes (alignment) | No | Limited |
| BlackLab Server | Apache 2.0 | Free | Self-host Linux; Docker | Yes (BL query) | Yes | Partial | Partial | No | Partial | Partial | No | Yes (REST) |
| ANNIS | Apache 2.0 | Free | Self-host Linux; Docker | Yes (AQL) | Yes (multi-layer) | Partial | No | No | Partial | Partial | No | Yes (REST) |
| Korp | MIT | Free | Self-host Linux; Docker | Yes (CQP) | Yes | Yes | Keywords; no terms | No | Yes | Yes | No | Yes (REST) |
| KorAP | Mixed OSS (Apache/AGPL) | Free | Self-host Linux; Docker | Yes (Poliqarp/CQP-like) | Yes | Partial | Partial | No | Partial | Partial | No | Yes (REST) |
| Poliqarp | GPL v2 | Free | Self-host Linux | Yes (Poliqarp) | Yes | Basic | No | No | Partial | No | No | Limited |
| TXM / TXM Portal | GPL v3 | Free | Desktop; Server on Linux | Yes (CQP) | Yes | Yes | Keywords; limited terms | No | Yes | Partial | No | Limited |
| Voyant Tools | GPL v3 | Free | Self-host (Java); SaaS | Partial (regex; no CQL) | Partial | Yes | Yes | No | Yes | No | No | Limited (widgets) |
| TEITOK | GPL v3 | Free | Self-host Linux (PHP/MySQL) | Partial (CQP via backends) | Yes | Partial | Partial | No | Partial | Yes | No | Limited |
| PML-TQ | GPL | Free | Self-host Linux | Graph/tree queries | Yes | No | No | No | No | Partial (treebanks) | No | Yes (HTTP) |
| Grew / Grew-match | CeCILL-C | Free | Self-host Linux; Docker | Graph queries (not CQL) | Yes | No | No | No | No | No | No | Yes |
| Text-Fabric | Apache 2.0 | Free | Self-host Linux (Python) | Custom TF queries | Yes (if annotated) | Partial (via code) | No | No | No | Partial | No | Yes (Python) |
| OpenSearch/Lucene stack (custom) | Apache 2.0 | Free | Self-host; Docker/K8s | No (custom) | Yes (if indexed) | Partial (via scripts) | Partial | No | Yes | Partial | No (integrate crawlers) | Yes (REST) |
| corporaexplorer (R) | MIT | Free | Self-host Linux (R Shiny) | Partial (regex; no CQL) | No/Partial | Partial | Yes (keywords) | No | Yes | No | No | No |
